comments.commentBody: How incredible that the words 'American' and 'interrogator' now have the same effect seen on the page  as, say, 'Gestapo sadist' or 'KGB brute'. So much for Bush and Cheney and the various foul fiends (yes, we need Shakespeare at this hour) who betrayed not just America but western civilization.

The US with its invasion of Iraq, extra-judicial killings, collateral damage, indefinite detention without charge,use of torture and drones bombing anyone who looks vaguely like a suspect makes a mockery of concept liberty. The Republicans are worried about the 1% and how they will possibly be able to get by with a slightly higher tax.

True. But in one speech he changed the debate and we Democrats are ascendant while a Republican Congress is left to tear itself apart.

comments.commentBody:
For those who say none of Obama's goals can be achieved with a Republican controlled Congress, keep this in mind: he is in a BETTER position now than when the Republicans had only the House. Now, they are fully in charge of one branch of government. Before, the House could block and the Senate could stall and the public, not paying attention to details and misled by an overly cautious, fearful national media, could blame Obama for what Congress refused to do.

"He should be a better leader." "He should reach across the isle." "He should negotiate with the Republicans." Ignorant of facts, this is what many people have said for the last four years. Now it is time for the Republicans to put up or shut up.

By proposing a more bold agenda, he sets the stage: either the Republicans decide to give and get, to compromise in order to get some of what they want, or they will wind up with nothing. Nothing but impeachment to make them happy. Ultimately, the public will now blame Congress for the gridblocking they've been doing all along.

Before, the Republicans could dodge and weave. Now they have to actually participate in running the government or risk looking like fools.

Doug Terry
